did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: James W. McKinnon Music Iconography Slide Collection, circa 1960-1980
did.langmaterial: No textual materials are included in the collection.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: The James W. McKinnon Music Iconography Slide Collection consists of 2,380 slide reproductions of iconographic sources related to music. Images in the collection feature representations of musicians, instruments, and musical notation in manuscript illuminations, prints, engravings, oil paintings, sculptural and architectural works, mosaics, reliefs, and other artworks.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], James W. McKinnon Music Iconography Slide Collection, circa 1960-1980, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access and Use
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: James W. McKinnon (1932 - 1999) was an American musicologist known for his contributions to the study of Western plainchant, medieval and renaissance music, Latin liturgy, and music iconography. He published more than 100 articles in music journals and reference books; authored several books including The Temple, The Church Fathers, and Early Western Chant, and The Advent Project: The Later Seventh-Century Creation of the Roman Mass Proper; and edited collections including Source Readings in Music History and Music in Early Christian Literature.

McKinnon was born in Niagara Falls, NY, in 1932. He received a BA in classical languages from Niagara University and a PhD in musicology from Columbia University. He joined the faculty at University at Buffalo in 1966 and remained through 1989, serving as acting music department chair from 1968-70 and from 1980-81, and as music department chair from 1987-89. From the mid-1960s to 1988, he also served as church organist and choirmaster at St. John’s-Grace Episcopal Church in Buffalo.
In 1989 he was appointed Richard H. Fogel Professor of Music at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, a position he held until his death in 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The James W. McKinnon Music Iconography Slide Collection consists of 2380 slide reproductions of iconographic sources related to music. The collection was established by former UB music department chair James W. McKinnon, and has been developed and maintained by the UB Music Library. The core of the collection was generated through McKinnon’s research, which identified source materials for the analysis and interpretation of musical subject matter in works of art.

Images in the collection feature representations of musicians, instruments, and musical notation in manuscript illuminations, prints, engravings, oil paintings, sculptural and architectural works, mosaics, reliefs, and other artworks. The bulk of the collection represents Western European works created from the 9th through the 16th centuries and held in European and American library and museum collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Slides are arranged in order by accession number.

note.p: This preliminary finding aid includes item-level descriptions of 1754 of the 2380 slides in the collection. Links to digitized versions of the images will currently work only for University at Buffalo staff and students. The item-level descriptions of the remaining 626 slides will be added to the container list upon completion of processing.

Depicts 10 musicians playing bagpipes, large and small drums, cymbals, bells, double trumpet, bowed stringed instrument, portative organ, psaltery, and mandora. An organologically impossibly instrument, the double trumpet was a medieval misconception of the Greek aulos.
